descript.abstract: The data here are orthomosaics, digital surface models (DSMs), and individual frames captured during low altitude airborne flights in 2013 at the Barrow Environmental Observatory. The orthomosaics, thermal IR mosaics, and DSMs were generated from the individual frames using Structure from Motion techniques. Dataset DOI:10.5440/1167159.
descript.purpose: Data were collected to characterize the optical and thermal properties of the landscape and how they differ between two points in time with different vegetative and hydrologic conditions.

stratum.stratkey: Frozen Ground; Surface; Ground; Digital Mapping; Land Cover; Visible Imagery; Topography; Aerial Photography;

idinfo.useconst: No use constraints are associated with this data.
idinfo.datacred: Supported by the U.S. DOE Arctic NGEE program and the Alaska Climate Science Center. The LiDAR dataset used for accuracy assessment was provided by Cathy Wilson(cjw@lanl.gov) and Chandana Gangodagamage(chandana@lanl.gov).

qattracc.attraccv: No formal uncertainty assessments were conducted and no estimates of uncertainty are reported.

dataqual.logic: Data are considered of good quality in the context of the information presented in the abstract. Users are advised to read the rest of the metadata record carefully for additional details.
dataqual.complete: Data are considered complete in the context of the information presented in the abstract. Users are advised to read the rest of the metadata record carefully for additional details.

cntperp.cntorg: Next-Generation Ecosystem Experiments (NGEE) Arctic Project, Oak Ridge National Laboratory

metainfo.metstdn: FDGC Content Standard for Digital Geospatial Metadata and Biological Data Profile

ome.datause: The orthomosaic tiles, thermal IR mosaics, and DSMs are geotiffs in NAD 83 UTM Zone 4 named by their lower-left coordinate. Metadata for the raw imagery are contained in the .exif headers in the files for the optical imagery only. XYZ files contain the IR temperatures at various longitudes and latitudes.
